I have a question for Pat Robertson, and for that matter, all other 
Christians who believe in the Bible but do not believe in a literal 6 
day creation.

As Christians, we believe that the Omniscient, Omnipotent, Omnipresent, 
creator of this universe, sent His Son to the earth, born of a virgin.

He lived on this planet 33 years of a perfect life, and preformed miracles 
to include walking on water, healing the sick and crippled. He raised the 
dead yet allowed himself to be captured, beaten, spit upon, crucified, and 
eventually gave up His own life in the brutal death on a cross. Most 
importantly, that blood, His blood, will be our atoning sacrifice when we 
stand before God's judgment.

On the third day after the crucifixion, Christ's dead body was taken from 
that cross and placed inside a tomb where he lay for 3 days. But on the 
third day, he Came back to life, was seen by over a hundred people after 
rising from the dead in the weeks before he ascended back into heaven to 
prepare a place for us when we die.

Then we ,as Christians, ask the unsaved to believe the history of our 
faith, and not to worry about Genesis 1-11. This has been a difficult issue 
for me in my 46 year history. I have learned that God can do whatever He 
wants, it doesn't have to make sense to me, check out Job 38.

Am I really suppose to tell the unbelievers that the same God that 
brought His Son to the earth to suffer the punishment of sin for me, so I 
have the opportunity to believe in Him and accept Him as my Lord 
and Savior, isn't the same God that created this universe in 6 literal 
days. 

Am I to tell them that the same God that judged the world in a global 
flood, with global earthquakes and tsunamis, splitting the earths crust 
of Pangaea and dividing the continents, that made mountains rise, and 
valleys fall, and destroyed every living thing on this planet, due to their 
evil, "don't worry about believing that"? "It's o.k. to believe instead 
in uniformitarianism, because the way things are today, is the way 
they have always been."  

Am I to tell them to just be concerned that they believe in Jesus and make 
a decision to put their faith in Him before they die, or before Christ 
returns to the earth for His people, "Christians"? Yes, that is what I 
believe we are to do, and we are motivated by the Holy Spirit, and the 
brevity of life to do so, as well as the fact that we shall all stand 
before God's judgment. We share our faith based upon the Bible, and backed 
up by there by 2nd Timothy 3:16, with everyone? By the way, that same Bible 
tell us not only what is going to happen in the future, but what happened 
in the beginning as well.

Since we know what the Bible tells us, aren't we allowing the lines that we 
draw, confuse us, as well as the non-Christians?﻿

Okay, it's high time somebody spoke out about this Creationism debate. 
First off, there are a great deal of Creationists, like myself, who believe 
in the Old Earth creationism theory that our planet is older than 6,000 
years. Many of my college professors have presented the evidence to back 
this up, and it's quite obvious to me that our planet is truly ancient. But 
just because of it's alleged age, does that mean there's no way that a 
supreme being could have created Earth billions of years ago? Absolutely 
not--too many Creationists take everything the Bible says literally. Yes, 
it's a bloodline that adds up to 6,000 years, but how do we know the Bible 
is telling us everything that happened? It says the world was created in 
seven days, not seven CONSECUTIVE days. We can see the proof if dinosaurs 
from millions of years ago. We know it happened, because the fossil 
evidence proves it. But who's to say that God didn't create the dinosaurs 
one day and then millions of years later create man? Now I'm no 
paleontologist, and I may not be precise with the timeline of dinosaur life 
on Earth, but it seems plausible to me to think that God created the 
different aspects of our planet on different days through--as far as we 
know--billions of years. Now you may say the Bible isn't relevant because 
so much is unexplained. But of course the Bible isn't gonna tell us EVERY 
SINGLE THING that was created and when it was so. God made man with the 
ability to think and discover. Wouldn't he want us to find out these things 
ourselves? And He was in no hurry to create light, the stars and planets, 
and all life on Earth. So why MUST it always be seven consecutive days? I 
believe in The Lord God Almighty who created this big, wonderful, ancient 
world and breathed life into every living being on this Earth, and created 
an infinite cosmos for man to discover and love.﻿

The universe is timeless, ageless even, then again so is everything from

The motion of the galaxy around the universe? Round it all goes, and it all 
repeats again and again forever. If you could imagine the universe like 
coffee in a cup, then the coffee has always been there, its not even 
evaporating lol It may be swirling about in the cup, but its there same as 
it always was, same as it always will be, infinity comes to mind. If you 
could expand beyond the universe, ever larger and larger to the point the 
universe itself it nothing more then a tiny dot, from this angle the 
universe has no time at all, its just a dot, again same as it always was 
and will be. There are mini baby booms happening all throughout the 
universe, this was your big boom, but not universal, in truth it was 
nothing but one of the many little big booms, happening all the time 
throughout the universe. So from the right perspectives you can see how 
time is many things to many people, from one angle is nothing more then a 
spin that repeats, and yet from another angle does not even exist at all.﻿

Ultimately, the age of the earth cannot be proven. Whether 6000 years or 
billions of years, both viewpoints (and everything in between) rest on 
faith and assumptions. Those who hold to billions of years trust that 
methods such as radiometric dating are reliable and that nothing has 
occurred in history that may have disrupted the normal decay of 
radio-isotopes. Those who hold to 6000 years trust that the Bible is true 
and that other factors explain the "apparent" age of the earth, such as the 
global flood, or God's creating the universe in a state that "appears" to 
give it a very long age. For example, God created Adam and Eve as 
fully-grown adult human beings. If a doctor had examined Adam and Eve on 
the day of their creation, the doctor would have estimated their age at 20 
years (or whatever age they appeared to be) when, in fact, Adam and Eve 
were less than one day old. Whatever the case may be, I choose to trust the 
Word of God over the words of atheistic scientists with an evolutionary 
agenda.﻿

+Bruco Alidas Great, a cut & paste from ICR I'll check their sources. But

historical data on the intensity of the field only goes back to 1829. Was 
the field decaying before that? Fortunately, there is a scientific way to 
answer that question.

"Archaeomagnetism" is the study of the magnetization of bricks, pottery, 
campfire stones, and other man-related objects studied by archaeologists. 
Iron oxides in those objects retain a record of the strength and direction 
of the earth's magnetic field at the time they last cooled to normal 
temperatures. Archaeomagnetic data taken worldwide show that the intensity 
of the earth's magnetic field was about 40% greater in 1000 A.D. than it is 
today, and that it has declined steadily since then.[7]

Such a rapid decay could not have been going on continuously for millions 
of years, because the field would have to have been impossibly strong in 
the past in order for it to still exist today. Creationists of the 1970s 
extrapolated today's decay back into the past, showing that the field could 
not be more than about 10,000 years old, assuming a constant decay of 
intensity.

Unfortunately, the archaeomagnetic data do not support that assumption.[7] 
Instead, the data show that the field intensity at the earth's surface 
fluctuated wildly up and down during the third millennium before Christ 
(see figure 1). A final fluctuation slowly increased the intensity until it 
reached a peak (50% higher than today) at about the time of Christ. Then it 
began a slowly accelerating decrease. By about 1000 A.D., the decrease was 
nearly as fast as it is today.

+Bruco Alidas The Pleiades are a prominent sight in winter in both the 
Northern Hemisphere and Southern Hemisphere, and have been known since 
antiquity to cultures all around the world, including the Māori, Aboriginal 
Australians, the Persians, the Arabs (known as Thurayya), the Chinese, the 
Japanese, the Maya, the Aztec, and the Sioux and Cherokee. In Tamil culture 
this star cluster is attributed to Lord Murugan (Lord Murugan raised by the 
six sisters known as the Kārththikai Pengal and thus came to be known as 
Kārtikeyan). In Sanskrit he is known as Skanda.
The Nebra sky disk, dated c. 1600 BC. The cluster of dots in the upper 
right portion of the disk is believed to be the Pleiades.
The Babylonian star catalogues name the Pleiades MUL.MUL or "star of 
stars", and they head the list of stars along the ecliptic, reflecting the 
fact that they were close to the point of vernal equinox around the 23rd 
century BC. The earliest known depiction of the Pleiades is likely a bronze 
age artifact known as the Nebra sky disk, dated to approximately 1600 BC. 
Some Greek astronomers considered them to be a distinct constellation, and 
they are mentioned by Hesiod, and in Homer's Iliad and Odyssey. They are 
also mentioned three times in the Bible (Job 9:9 and 38:31, as well as Amos 
5:8). The Pleiades (Krittika) are particularly revered in Hindu mythology 
as the six mothers of the war god Murugan, who developed six faces, one for 
each of them. Some scholars of Islam

"So how can someone say how much has decayed?"

because it has been observed how much of a radioactive element exists when 
a process starts.

i will use carbon dating as an example: Carbon 14 is created at a fairly 
constant rate in the atmosphere due to solar radiation. when a plant is 
alive, it intakes the C14 and C12 through photosynthesis. the ratio remains 
constant while the process continues. (that is how we know what ratio to 
start with.) when the plant dies, it stops the intake of carbon and the C14 
begins to decay at a very constant rate, being replaced by more C12. this 
is called its half-life. scientists can test the ratio between C14 and C12 
and discover how long ago that plant died, (and by extension, animals that 
eat those plants... etc.), by checking the decay rate.

"A few verified examples of incorrect radiometric ages are simply 
insufficient to prove that radiometric dating is invalid. All they indicate 
is that the methods are not infallible. Those of us who have developed and 
used dating techniques to solve scientific problems are well aware that the 
systems are not perfect; we ourselves have provided numerous examples of 
instances in which the techniques fail. We often test them under controlled 
conditions to learn when and why they fail so we will not use them 
incorrectly. We have even discredited entire techniques. For example, after 
extensive testing over many years, it was concluded that uranium-helium 
dating is highly unreliable because the small helium atom diffuses easily 
out of minerals over geologic time. As a result, this method is not used 
except in rare and highly specialized applications. Other dating 
techniques, like K-Ar (potassium-argon and its more recent variant 
40Ar/39Ar), Rb-Sr (rubidium-strontium), Sm-Nd (samarium-neodynium), Lu-Hf 
(lutetium-hafnium), and U-Pb (uranium-lead and its variant Pb-Pb), have all 
stood the test of time. These methods provide valuable and valid age data 
in most instances, although there is a small percentage of cases in which 
even these generally reliable methods yield incorrect results. Such 
failures may be due to laboratory errors (mistakes happen), unrecognized 
geologic factors (nature sometimes fools us), or misapplication of the 
techniques (no one is perfect). In order to accomplish their goal of 
discrediting radiometric dating, however, creationists are faced with the 
daunting task of showing that a preponderance of radiometric ages are wrong 
— that the methods are untrustworthy most of the time. Not only that, they 
have to show the flaws in those dating studies that provide independent 
corroborative evidence that radiometric methods work. This is a tall order 
and the creationists have made no progress so far."

+Forest B. "Do you know for 100% certain that it is infallible?"

yes, i do. the decay rate of radioactive elements is one of the most stable 
and easily predictable occurrences in our universe. temperature, pressure, 
and gravity do not affect this. there is a slight change in rate due to 
chemical interaction with a few isotopes but the change is measured as less 
than a percent. the only major change ever observed in decay rate involves 
ionizing the atom, (stripping it of its elections). this requires a large 
amount of electrical energy. the energy needed over time to effect decay in 
any meaningful way is massive. it can't be replicated naturally.

"If scientist say something is 1000 years old, is it possible that it could 
be 1001 years old? Or maybe 1500 years?"

there is around a 5% margin of error. scientists never say something is 
*exactly* # years old. they always say it is around that number. still, 
dating rocks to millions of years using Potassium-Argon dating with a 5% 
margin of error still shows the rock is millions of years old. there is no 
getting around that. if that is the case, the earth is not only 6,000 
years, or even 10,000 years old. it is, *in fact* millions of years old.

young age is the volcanic island chains, such as the Hawaiian islands. 
These islands were formed by hotspots in the earth's mantle (such as the 
Hawaii hotspot), that spew out magma that dries into volcanic islands. 
However, the earth's plates move, causing a chain of smaller extinct 
volcanos to form, rather than a single large active volcano.

Example one:

Two strains of Drosophila paulistorum developed hybrid sterility of male 
offspring between 1958 and 1963. Artificial selection induced strong 
intra-strain mating preferences.
(Test for speciation: sterile offspring and lack of interbreeding affinity.)

Dobzhansky, Th., and O. Pavlovsky, 1971. "An experimentally created 
incipient species of Drosophila", Nature 23:289-292.

Example two:

Evidence that a species of fireweed formed by doubling of the chromosome 
count, from the original stock. (Note that polyploids are generally 
considered to be a separate "race" of the same species as the original 
stock, but they do meet the criteria which you suggested.)
(Test for speciation: cannot produce offspring with the original stock.)

Mosquin, T., 1967. "Evidence for autopolyploidy in Epilobium angustifolium 
(Onaagraceae)", Evolution 21:713-719

Example three:

Rapid speciation of the Faeroe Island house mouse, which occurred in less 
than 250 years after man brought the creature to the island.
(Test for speciation in this case is based on morphology. It is unlikely 
that forced breeding experiments have been performed with the parent stock.)

Stanley, S., 1979. Macroevolution: Pattern and Process, San Francisco, W.H. 
Freeman and Company. p. 41

Example four:

Formation of five new species of cichlid fishes which formed since they 
were isolated less than 4000 years ago from the parent stock, Lake Nagubago.
(Test for speciation in this case is by morphology and lack of natural 
interbreeding. These fish have complex mating rituals and different 
coloration. While it might be possible that different species are 
inter-fertile, they cannot be convinced to mate.)

Mayr, E., 1970. Populations, Species, and Evolution, Massachusetts, Harvard 
University Press. p. 348

+WIllyGilly321 Your characterization of origin of life theories shows that 
you have not taken the time to actually understand any of the origin of 
life science. There is NO satisfactory scientific definition for life, 
because *the distinction between life and non-life is arbitrary*. Some say 
that life is matter that reproduces itself through thermodynamic collision 
of molecules, which include chemical molecules like self-replicating RNA 
strands, but does not include viruses as living things; others require a 
metabolism, which means that an RNA strand is not alive by this definition. 
I personally would consider a single self-replicating molecule to be alive, 
but again the definition of life is based on opinion. The very first "life" 
was probably RNA strands inside of phospholipid membranes, the same type of 
membrane used by modern bacteria, which self-assemble into spherical 
vesicles when put into a water medium.

there to watch over the rock for 55 million years to make sure it never

sealed in a container to prevent infiltration or leaching of minerals.

and "showed" themselves to be millions of years old by these methods, and 
with great variations of ages amongst the different tests. This is certain 
proof that the methods are highly flawed.

Christian doctrine. There are excellent Christian teachers who believe that 
the earth is older than 6,000 years (10 million, 10 billion, and such.), 
but don't refute that God created it all. My question to people who believe 
in evolution is; If you think what Christians believe about Creationism is 
a joke and fantasy then why are you even wasting your time debating and 
trying to disprove it? You might as well debate people who believe in space 
aliens or feng shui! Just wave it off with your hand and go about your day. 
The real reason you debate creationism is because your conscience is 
pricked. God created every single person that walked on this planet, and 
just because you choose not to believe in God does not make Him not real. 
The God-given created conscience that everyone of us has cries out to Him. 
It's why human beings don't behave like crocodiles or sharks, and when one 
of us does act so, we have police, laws, courts, and a justice system - and 
hopefully a moral conscience!. It's also why we have charities, celebrate 
birth, mourn death, go to plays, go to school, go to work, have pets, have 
libraries, fly to the moon, split atoms, and feed and take care of our 
families and look out for neighbors we don't even know - we are different 
than an amoeba, a fish or a chimpanzee. May you come to know Him! God 
Bless!﻿

something extreme or easy to argue against--that they know their opponent 
doesn't support. You put forth a straw man because you know it will be easy 
for you to knock down or discredit. It's a way of misrepresenting your 
opponent's position.

Neither young or old earth creationism are essential to salvation or are 
100% accurate biblically. They are plausible doctrines but are not 
inerrant.Both are doctrines that were thought up by someone. Genesis was 
written in a poetic form and in the original language, which is hebrew mind 
you not english, the word for day is transliterated as "yom" with a long 
"o." "Yom" is not confined to a 24 hour day, and since one of the 
fundamental beliefs in Christianity is that God is Transcendent (not bound 
by time) that it is not factual but it is plausible that the earth could be 
older than 6,000-10,000 years. The first "day" it says "the earth was 
formless and empty and darkness was over the surface of the deep and the 
spirit of God hovered over the waters. and God said 'let there be light' 
and there was light…" Genesis 1. it then goes on to say that God separated 
the light from the darkness and called it day and night. there is no way to 
tell how long God hovered over the waters or how long the first day even 
was. before the fall, there could have been a longer day. meaning instead 
of it only being 24 hours it could have been longer or shorter. therefore 
we have no idea how long God took to make the earth. What we do know is 
that God is sovereign and powerful enough to create (Hebrew "Bara") it 1 
second, 6 days, or 100 million years. That's the entire point of it all. 
it's not that Young earth's are right, and Old earth's are wrong or vice 
versa, the point is that both are plausible and God is able enough to do 
either. It breaks me to see disunity over something that isn't even 
essential to salvation. the entire point of the Genesis account and the 
entire OT is the story of God putting his family back together through the 
Messiah, Christ Jesus. I know many people who have different beliefs in

point is that God is sovereign and in complete control of the earth and had

coming back)  is sound it shouldn't matter how one believes about little 
things. Those in Christ are all unified by His blood, not by the view of

+ardentchateau 

1. You seem to have a fundamental misunderstanding of what proof is. You 
CANNOT prove a claim by example; it is a logical fallacy. You CAN disprove 
a claim by counterexample, however. These are simple rules of logic. For 
example, say we make the claim that all apples are red. If, soon after, we 
come across a red apple, this by no means proves that all apples are red, 
only that the one that we found is red. But If I were to say that all 
apples are red and then find a green apple, this DISPROVES the claim that 
all apples are red. In regard to the Bible... let me give you the benefit 
of the doubt and agree that the prophecies to which you refer have indeed 
come true (I can't say that I know what you are referring to). These are 
only examples, and they cannot prove that the entirety of the Bible is true 
and authentic just like one red apple cannot prove that all apples are red. 
Also, they are events which could have come to pass with or without the 
Bible prophesies having been written. The mere fact that these examples in 
the Bible came to pass in the real world does not by any means prove the 
Bible's authenticity. Examples do offer probabilistic proof. However, if we 
are going to go delve into probability, the amount of things in the book of 
Genesis that probabilistically could not have happened (usually with 
statistical significance of 5%) FAR outweigh those that could have (if 
there are any).

2. How does me making the point that you cannot prove the word of God is 
authentic make me "love sin and hate good"? Is it because I used logic to 
reach that conclusion rather than faith? I am not claiming that God does 
not exist, nor am I claiming that he does. I simply claim that you cannot 
PROVE his word as written in the Bible is authentic (nor can you prove his 
existence for that matter). This is why it is called faith.
